title: Wednesday, 20th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Quite a bit going on

PM

Rather than any smart ass picture i think we'll just get some tin hats up

11:00 am
PM

tinhat tinhat tinhat

PM

We have a special guest today

PM

Paul Donovan

11:01 am
PM

UBS global economist is here at FTAV HQ

PM

You can read some of his recent commentary here https://www.ubs.co.../paul_donovan.html

PM

You can order his most recent book here! : http://www.amazon....th+about+invlation

11:01 am
PM

thumbs up

PM

Paul -- welcome!

PM

Paul is here first and foremost to discuss the latest UBS white paper for Davos

11:02 am
PM

Which is here: https://www.ubs.co...ts/davos-2016.html

PD

Thanks very much. The fourth industrial revolution in many ways reverses some of the economic and social consequences of the first industrial revolution. More self employment. More autonomy. Changing transport. More local production. This is something that is going to impact equality (returns to skills keep rising), value of economic growth etc. Emerging markets tend to suffer, developed economies tend to do better as a result of this. Switzerland not China is a beneficiary. This is not just that low skilled, low cost jobs disappear, it is really about the flexibility of labour and skills, and intellectual property rights. EM tends not to perform so well there.

PM

Ok, that's a quick summary

11:03 am
PM

Can you run us through the winners and losers here

PD

So the current issues in EM perhaps need to be seen in the context of this bigger structural shift

PD

to win you need to have a skilled workforce

11:04 am
PD

ut also a flexibly skilled workforce

PM

(TheLeggie -- behave)

PD

if you produce hundreds of engineers who have learned their craft by rote leading, Gradgrind style, their skills will be obsolete in a decade

11:04 am
PD

you need to train people and train people to be able to adapt as well

PD

(and I am not a robot, just an economist. A more evolved form of homo sapien)

PM

Particular interest over on the right as to how China fairs in all this

11:05 am
PM

Thoughts there?

PD

absolutely. Not well

PD

they have skills up to a point, but flexibility is not a noted feature of the education system

11:06 am
PD

another problem is legal rights

PM

hmm

PD

you end up trading virtual design not physical product

11:06 am
PD

if you have no legal guarantee your design is safe, you don't trade

PD

a more virtual world needs more legal guarantees

PD

One of the dangers is that as labour markets change, governments try to regulate to protect specific professions

11:07 am
PD

a bit like medieval guilds

PM

indeed

PD

or journalism

11:08 am
PD

if that is the case then there is a risk that countries fall behind

PD

need to embrace the change, not preserve professions in aspic

PM

Embrace the machines

11:08 am
PM

Even in journalism

PM

How about winners amongst the developed countries?

PM

US way ahead here, is it?

11:08 am
PD

Switzerland comes out as number one

PD

was a conincidence, I promise

PM

haha

11:09 am
PD

however the top group cluster together

PD

Anglo Saxons do well (generally as a result of labour and skills flexibility and rule of law)

PD

Singapore does well, the Swiss, assorted northern European economies

11:10 am
PD

EM cluster to the bottom of the table, and countries like Korea, Spain and China are middle ranking

PM

Fair enough

undefined
11:10 am
PM

So Paul

PM

Away from the Davos talking shop

PM

THoughts on general markets volatility

11:11 am
PM

Do we have to embrace that as well

PM

It's tiring!

PD

I think there are a couple of problems with markets and economics at the moment. There has been a divorce

11:11 am
PD

markets are not reacting to economic fundamentals

PD

deed a quite brilliant paper from UBS on global economic surprises made that clear just this morning

PD

what is happening is less about economics and more about perceptions

11:11 am
PD

issue is should economists care? And the answer at the moment is not that much

PD

feedback from markets to economics is limited

PD

cost of capital not really a constraint on companies at the moment, so market moves not a problem there

11:12 am
PD

wealth effects limited. More Americans own a cat than own equity. Most Americans own a house

PM

ha!

PD

house prices keep on rising

11:12 am
PD

not too fussed by feedback at this stage

PM

This is bold stuff -- saying markets have decoupled from the real economy

PD

Think about the S&P. S&P companies generate about 15% (sic) of US GDP. Half their earnings come from overseas. And (off the top of my head) S&P is 45% mining and production. US economy is 15% mining and production (85% services). What on earth has the S&P to do with reality in the US economy?

11:14 am
PM

hmm

PM

Fair enough

PD

This is an SME recovery at the moment anyway - US and Europe. Listed companies are not the story, it is the mom and pop stores, the Mittelstand that are driving

11:14 am
PM

Right

PM

Thanks for all that Paul

PM

After the Inflation book, I suspect you have another book in you soon

11:15 am
PM

Any thoughts on themes?

PD

The next issue for me is the key one for the 21st century IMHO. Human capital is going to dominate, to go back to the issues of the fourth industrial revolution. Maximising human capital becomes key

PD

problem is that change encourages prejudice, and prejudice destroys human capital

11:17 am
PM

Very interesting -- so we should be embracing migrants as well as machines

PD

look at some of the politics on both sides of the Atlantic - the hostility, the rise of "anti" parties, is very destructive to economics

PM

Absolutely

11:17 am
PD

nationality, race, gender, orientation...

PD

prejudice comes in many forms

PD

there is even occasionally prejudice against economists

11:17 am
PM

No!

PD

nothing could be more economically destructive than that

PM

hehe

11:17 am
PM

Thanks for joining us Paul

PM

We'll let you go

PD

thanks for the invite, and the questions

11:18 am
PM

One more plug for the book: http://www.amazon....th+about+invlation

PM

Hurry -- only 7 left in stock at Amazon

PD

get the unsigned versions. They have scarcity value

11:18 am
PM

Cheers

undefined
BE

And, that's my queue to step in.

11:19 am
BE

Thanks to Mr Donovan for raising the tone. Now I can revert it back to mean.

BE

And we really need to start with the scores.

BE

FTSE off 3%.

11:20 am
BE

Down 173 points at 5703.

BE

I make the FTSE's "bear market" trigger at about 5685, so that looks highly possible.

PM

Blimey

11:21 am
PM

Could even get it this session

PM

If we try hard

BE

(Using the usual definition of a bear market being 20% below the previous peak close. Why it's not done on intraday I don't know.)

11:21 am
BE

In terms of what's down: everything.

PM

Capitulation in the miners tho

BE

Certainly. But also, about a third of the FTSE 100 is at a 52-week low.

11:22 am
BE

It's not a discriminate selloff. It's just a selloff.

PM

Hmm

PM

You know there was a prior plan for Neil Hume to come back on here this morning

11:23 am
BE

Oh! Really?

PM

He wanted to get the Rabble's view on whether he should sell Pearson now or wait until after tomorrow's trading update

PM

He has a few shares left

11:23 am
PM

Having somehow not seen our advice on the matter

PM

(RUN)

PM

Wondered whether he should sell now to avoid another profit warning

11:24 am
PM

Or hold to see whether there was something upbeat in the statement

PM

Such as

PM

(cough)

11:24 am
PM

A management change

PM

But then he saw the price this morning and it was all too much for him

PM

The stock's out the door. Couldnt wait any longer

11:25 am
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 663.50, down 21 (-3.07%), High: 675.00, Low: 644.50, Volume: 2.19m
BE

Hm. Liberum's Ian Whittaker has chosen the day before the trading update to drop forecasts.

BE

We reiterate Pearson as our key Sell within the media sector and reduce our target price to 540p (from 640p). We reduce estimates and the target price ahead of tomorrow’s trading update, despite Pearson benefiting from a strengthening dollar. It is widely recognised that 2016 will be a difficult year for Pearson but we think the market still does not recognise the full extent of the secular issues. We think there is a significant chance of further restructuring charges and there is a risk to the dividend.

11:26 am
BE

Pearson is our key structural Sell with US higher education (38% of FY16E profits) being our single biggest area of concern as students buy fewer books.

We do not assume any significant new restructuring costs within our forecasts but, given the secular pressures, this is a key risk to ours and consensus estimates.

We only cut FY16E earnings by 1% given the FX tailwind PSON should enjoy but cut FY17E by 10% as the impact of organic revenue declines takes a toll.

We assume flat dividends of 51p in our forecasts but even flat dividends may be unsustainable. PSON should consider reducing the dividend and use the cash to finance investment.

PM

Oh great, so the divi is now possibly toast as well

BE

Morgan Stanley also pre-emptively cut forecasts halfway through yesterday.

11:27 am
BE

In 2013 and 2014, Pearson downgraded current year expectations both at
the January trading update and again with the full year figures in February. We
therefore see a risk of some further abnormal restructuring in 2016. The
new Chairman Sidney Taurel ( ex Eli Lilly) arrived in January.

BE

We are at 58.5p of EPS for 2016. The recent consensus is c60p-61p for
2016.

BE

Pearson may take the opportunity to say that it won’t cut the 2015
dividend. We forecast a 52p dividend for 2015 ( interim up 6%, final flat)
which is a yield of 7.4%, but we then forecast a cut to 30p ( yield 4.3% ) for
2016.

11:28 am
BE

5. Pearson is lowly rated (6.3x EBITDA, p/e12x, FCF yield 7.8% for 2016) and
there is medium term EPS support (even another £100m restructuring would
reduce Pearson to 48p which at 15x implies a price of 720p).
6. The market may prefer to wait to see the potential downgrades,
restructuring, management action before moving in

BE

How on earth did we start with Pearson though?

PM

Sorry, my fault

11:00 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Anyway.

undefined
11:29 am
BE

So! In terms of the miners ..............

BE

BHP leading us down.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 582.70, down 44.4 (-7.08%), High: 600.00, Low: 580.60, Volume: 6.56m
11:30 am
BE

Production report's a bit weak, so while guidance is reiterated it looks more of a reach.

BE

More importantly though .......

BE

"In this environment, we are also committed to protecting our strong balance sheet so we have the financial flexibility to manage further volatility and take advantage of the expected recovery in copper and oil over the medium term."

11:31 am
BE

The assumption is that "strong balance sheet" and "financial flexibility" means no divi, or at least a drastically reduced one.

BE

And in answer to the question asked in previous sessions: BHP board reviews its divi twice annually.

BE

(Most boards just have an annual review, which I find extraordinary. But there we are.)

11:32 am
BE

So anyway, BHP can cut the div with interims next month.

BE

The next question is whether the 50% cut assumed by the consensus will be enough.

BE

Saving slightly more than $3bn. And with oil at $27: no. Not even close. Still cashflow negative.

11:33 am
BE

So it might instead choose the stealth rights issue option instead.

BE

Do read yesterday's session with regards a scrip divi, which'd involve an equity issuance of about 12% of its cap.

PM

I don't see the point of 50% cuts at all

11:33 am
PM

It's no more reputational pain 50 or 100

PM

In fact, 100 pc looks like you are properly acknowledging reality here

BE

Yup. Agree. Divi should've been cancelled in the weeks after Samarco. Those were good days to hide bad news.

11:34 am
BE

Let me get Cazenove to summarise where we are here.

BE

BHP has reported mixed Q2/H1’16 production results with iron ore and
energy coal weak, offset by stronger than expected contributions from
petroleum, copper and met coal. H1 underlying EBIT will include charges
of $425-575m related to a range of costs including redundancies, rig
termination, write downs, and tax charges. Exceptional items now also
include a $250-450m charge related to potential litigation and tax, in
addition to the previously announced $7.2bn (pre-tax) impairment at US
Onshore. The statement also reaffirms that BHP "are committed to
protecting [the] strong balance sheet so we have the financial flexibility to
manage further volatility”. We believe the combination of these additional
costs and cash flow pressure increases the likelihood of a dividend cut
with results (23 Feb). We retain our UW, with the risk of a greater than 50% dividend
cut material and not factored into consensus at this stage in our view.

PM

Amazed this is not in consensus yeet

11:36 am
PM

the divi cut

BE

As in, greater than 50% divi cut not in the consensus.

BE

(@Alchemy30: load of bull, as I hope what we wrote overnight emphasised.)

11:37 am
BE

While on the miners -- which are all down, of course -- Investec does the maths on the sector going into siege mode.

BE

As in, doing an Opec. Or a Marlboro. As in, keeping metals below operational cost until the marginal producers all go out of business.

BE

We believe that current markets reflect dynamics not seen since the aftermath of Japanese re-industrialisation in the 1980s. Our revised price deck reflects our view that commodity prices will remain at levels necessary to squeeze out a significant portion of current capacity while deterring new investment. Consequently, prices are expected to remain well into industry cost curves during our active forecast period.

11:38 am
PM

Blimey

BE

Although we make significant reductions in our forecast price deck, in our view the market has been valuing companies at spot prices for some time. This is especially true for companies whose very survival is in question due to high debt loadings. We do, however, believe that our forecast deck reflects a reasonable view of how commodity prices may evolve going forward.

BE

We note some significant milestones reached at the end of 2015. Most mining companies have now effectively cancelled any future expansionary capex and will mine existing assets for cash. We see further cost cutting as the only chance to rebuild industry margins. Dividends are expected to be cut heavily, including for industry stalwarts, BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. There is little reward for equity holders under this scenario.

11:39 am
BE

Debt remains the paramount concern for shareholders as equity values continue to fall. Bondholders are now priority, and promises by some companies to pay down debt are effectively made at shareholder expense. Reduced, or nil dividends, further dilution, selling assets that formerly offered growth – none of this is to the benefit of shareholders - apart from keeping the company alive.

BE

Asset impairments have already started and we observe that such write downs will re-set value benchmarks. We also expect further downgrades by credit agencies in the weeks to come. Until we know how deep the axe will cut, we keep our Investec Mining Clock at 3 o’clock, i.e., watch and wait. We wait for a significant “value event” (such as a major restructuring) to shock the market into value territory.

BE

We move to focus solely on our NPV estimates to determine target prices. In most cases, earnings will be de-minimis at our forecast prices – so PE metrics are largely irrelevant. Once assets are written down, earnings may return.

11:39 am
PM

tinhat

BE

So, buy gold. But don't do that either.

BE

Our preferred exposure to the sector remains gold, but we are increasingly concerned about the future for PGM’s given the rapid advance of electric vehicles, higher recycling, and challenges to diesel market share in Europe.

11:40 am
PM

Actually, Randgold is the only footsie riser at present

PM

BE

Want to see Investec's clock?

11:41 am
PM

sure

BE

PM

Excellent

11:41 am
BE

So, BHP goes down to sell. Glencore's still sell (of course). Anglo down to sell. Lonmin (!) down to sell.

PM

Lonmin???

BE

Target 29p. As in, 0.29p in old money.

11:42 am
BE

Lonmin (Sell, TP 29p). We remain sellers of Lonmin despite the company’s
47-for-1 rights issue to raise US$407m (gross). We have updated our numbers
to reflect the dilution and cash injection, as well as adjusting the reduced
production profile as guided. We have also incorporated FY15A financials.
Under our commodity price assumptions we see Lonmin’s business plan as
unviable and therefore retain our Sell recommendation.

BE

Anyway, that's enough of that.

undefined
11:43 am
BE

And so to oil. I guess.

PM

Remember when people used to say "Never sell Shell"

BE

Heh.

11:44 am
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,296, down 73.5 (-5.37%), High: 1,330, Low: 1,285, Volume: 5.41m
PM

But it's still buying BG

BE

Sure. I guess the gap against BG is quite interesting, but I'm not sure how to read it from an arb perspective.

11:44 am
BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 918.50, down 21.4 (-2.28%), High: 926.20, Low: 914.20, Volume: 6.32m
BE

Both company statements are equally dull, really. They've been extremely cautious not to say anything unexpected pre the votes.

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:46 am
BE

Shell has not had a good track record of performing well at the fourth quarter and in that regard we see an in-line set of earnings at the midpoint as a positive. A weaker than expected downstream result was offset by a much better than expected contribution from the Integrated Gas business and encouragingly impairments were negligible with gearing finishing the year up just 1.8pp y/y to 14%. Perhaps the most positive feature from the update this morning was from BG with full year production above the upper end of guidance and net cash flow 11% ahead of our estimate. This goes some way to help justify the timing of Shell’s proposed acquisition of BG and should in our view help firm up the likelihood of shareholders voting in favour of the deal next week. We rate both stocks Overweight with the spread on the implied offer price for BG and current share price more than 5%.

PM

(muppet central -- this is true)

BE

Ben van B says: "I'm pleased with Shell's operating performance in 2015, and the momentum in the company to reduce costs and to improve competitiveness. Bold, strategic moves shape our industry. The completion of the BG transaction, which we are expecting in a matter of weeks, will mark the start of a new chapter in Shell, to rejuvenate the company, and improve shareholder returns"

11:47 am
BE

So, both the numbers and the tone are broadly supportive of a deal going ahead.

BE

The shareholder overlaps mean a deal is quite likely to go ahead.

BE

So I guess, sell Shell because of what it's going to become. Perhaps we're too focused on this deal rather than viewing what happens after it.

11:49 am
PM

(Footsie below 5700 again)

undefined
BE

Pru mentioned on the right. Very weak post its investor day yesterday.

11:50 am
Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,319, down 73.24 (-5.26%), High: 1,370, Low: 1,304, Volume: 3.65m
PM

Yeah, i dont quite get this

PM

Strong solvency, good management

11:50 am
BE

Well, Zurich results aren't a positive.

PM

ok

BE

Zurich down 9% last I checked. General insurance unit still in an awful state.

11:52 am
BE

Imagine what state Zurich would be in now if we hadn't chucked sand into the process of it buying RSA ........

BE

..... anyway, as for Pru, investor day yesterday seems to have been negative on the divi.

BE

Deutsche has a good summary. Here it is.

11:53 am
BE

On the positive side, a solvency ratio of 190% at 1H15 (180%e at FY15 xd) was better than expected. However, management discouraged the view that there could be a dividend pick-up at some stage, which will be seen as a disappointment. On growth, which was the main reason we downgraded the shares earlier, the group remains strongly positioned long-term (as we have always acknowledged); however, there is greater uncertainty as to how this pans out near-term. In short, we don't see any reason to change our own forecasts, but note these are 4% below consensus for 2016e. Based on a 'normal' market outlook, this leaves the shares at a reasonable 11x 2017e, but it is hard to see scope for any material re-rating from here while growth expectations are slowing. And there is potential for the shares to de-rate further if macro fears worsen.

BE

Despite the better solvency, management discouraged any hopes of a positive surprise on the dividend, commenting that they stress-test this against a range of factors such that even in adverse market conditions they would still be able to grow it. As such, the message appears to be that we should expect the dividend to grow only in line with earnings - with any additional payouts unlikely to emerge while market conditions are volatile.
On the growth outlook, most of the presentations focused on the group's long-term positioning (which remains excellent and has not really been in doubt). On the nearer-term headwinds, however, the message was more mixed. In the US and at M&G, management acknowledged near-term uncertainties in the form of the DOL proposals and market headwinds in the US and combination of net outflows along with both fee and cost pressures at M&G. Meanwhile in the UK, a reduced emphasis on new bulk annuity sales (worth c£100m pa in first year profits) is likely to be a net negative for forecasts. Against this, management sounded a more resilient note around the Asian outlook, appearing more positive than we had assumed on HK sales in particular. Taking all this together, we still think that consensus growth expectations need to come lower.

undefined
11:54 am
PM

Pru yielding 3% -- find it strange the market was looking for a hike here

BE

Against a sector yielding about 5% I think, though. Pru's "growth plus stability" sales pitch seems to draw people in.

PM

Difficult to know what to talk about when everything's down

11:56 am
BE

It is. Unless we want to talk about WH Smith, which I don't overly.

PM

Trding update here

BE

Oil might be at a 12-year low and China might be stalling, but people can still be badgered into buying gigantic Galaxy bars at train stations.

11:57 am
BE

So I guess that's an investment case to cling onto.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,721, up 133 (+8.38%), High: 1,729, Low: 1,607, Volume: 397.78k
BE

Note, core WH Smith has also shrunk to the point that it's stopped shrinking.

11:58 am
BE

High Street like for like sales growth of 0% in the first 20 weeks

BE

Best number since 2003.

PM

(Fresh Footsie sell off seems to be underway)

11:59 am
PM

(Bear market beckons)

BE

(It's four points below where you last noted. You really are a misery glutton, Paul.)

PM

(so)

12:00 pm
BE

Here's RBC on WH Smith.

BE

Our view: We remain positive on WH Smith for its global travel rollout
potential, improving sales trends on the High Street, gross margin upside,
further cost savings and ongoing cash returns. WH Smith has just reported
its first positive High Street LFL sales in c.15 years and we reiterate our
Outperform rating on the shares.

BE

Strong Xmas IMS, raising PBT forecasts by 2% - for the first 20 weeks of
FY16 to 16 January WH Smith's Group LFL sales were +2% yoy, well ahead
of our -1% estimate, driven by a stronger-than-expected performance by
the High Street business, and we estimate gross margin was up around
+55bps for the period. Concerns over the High Street business has been a
key reason either not to own the stock or to be short and so we expect the
market to respond very positively to this statement. We have increased
our PBT forecasts by 2% due to the strength of High Street with peak
season for WH Smith's higher-rated Travel business still to come this
summer.
High Street well ahead of expectations - High Street LFL sales were flat
yoy, well ahead of our -4% yoy estimate, and were +2% yoy for the key 5-
week period to 2 January 2016.
High Street beat driven by Stationery - we estimate LFL was around +5%
yoy for the period for Stationery (with gross margin flat) which is WH
Smith's largest and most profitable category on the High Street (c.40% of
sales, c.50% of profit on the High Street). In Stationery we think WH Smith
benefitted from a number of Special Buys - e.g., of Shorty pens, Ladybird
gifting books and strong sales of single Christmas cards.
Books less of a drag than expected - we estimate Books LFL was -1% yoy
with gross margin +100bps, helped by the "adult colouring" trend and
News & Impulse LFL sales were +1% yoy with gross margin +100bps yoy.
Travel LFL slightly ahead of expectations - Travel LFL for the first 20 weeks
was +5% yoy, slightly ahead of our +4% estimate, with total sales up a
very strong +12% yoy. WH Smith is continuing to benefit from strong
employment trends in the UK economy and also from a shift in spend away
to leisure/travel categories. Space contribution during the period was
boosted by the opening of several stores at Sydney airport in December.
Valuation premium well deserved - WH Smith trades at c.16x cal. 16E
P/E versus the sector on closer to 14x, but with c.60% of EBIT coming
from Travel, strong sales and earnings momentum and very high earnings
visibility we think the shares have scope to re-rate further. We maintain
our price target at £19 based on the average of DCF and sum-of-the-parts
analysis and we reiterate our positive stance on the shares.

12:01 pm
BE

(@Boncoeur: back of envelope maths, note. There's a 10 point margin of error.)

undefined
PM

This theme that Paul Donovan was on earlier

12:02 pm
PM

That markets are 'wrong" -- or decoupled from the real economy

PM

It's gaining traction

PM

Probably not much. Olivier Blanchard, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund who is now free to share his personal thoughts on the economy, argues that there is nothing “fundamental” that can justify the market rout. There is “no evidence” of a collapse in Chinese growth; and it’s “difficult to think” that any negative effects of lower oil prices outweigh the positive ones. Here, Blanchard strikes a slightly different note than his IMF successor Maurice Obstfeld and Paul Krugman, as we discussed yesterday. But these are shades of nuance, not categorical differences.

12:02 pm
PM

Taht's from Martin Sandbu daily email

PM

Which you should sign up for Rabble

PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3xmkxnnKf

12:03 pm
PM

sign up here http://nbe.ft.com/nbe/profile.cfm

BE

And do. It's very good.

PM

Also, while we are bossing the Rabble around

12:04 pm
PM

Do follow: https://twitter.com/DavosDeville

PM

She's a scream

PM

Izzy is in Davos as well as Ms Deville

12:04 pm
PM

Both wearing fur coats

undefined
BE

We're over time but, since it's a selloff day, I just wanted also to note the IPO pipeline.

12:05 pm

In anticipation of the "market conditions" pull announcements.

BE

We have CMC Markets due at the end of February, which is something of a double down on the current volatility. Goldman leading that I think.

12:07 pm

undefined

Chad_john -- it used to be 3% up/down

PM

12:11 pm
PM

Cheers Rabble

PM

Back tomorrow at 11am, unless the floor really drops out of this thing...

PM

Bye

12:12 pm
PM

5692

PM

wink smile

BE

Oil's at a 12-year low. Miners are enjoying their own private 2008. And we start with a textbook publisher.
